Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps Site: A Biological Sciences Site for the California State University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is an I-Corps project from the California State University (CSU) Program for Education and Research in Biotechnology (CSUPERB) for an I-Corps Biological Sciences Site. The activities proposed aim to smooth the development path for nascent academic entrepreneurs across the CSU. The Site recognizes the learning obstacles along the path to biological sciences commercialization including cultural differences between academic research and commercial development, product regulation, intellectual property management, and financing for long product development cycles.

CSUPERB will:
1) Recruit biological sciences researchers and fund 30 Site Teams annually, providing opportunities to explore biotechnology commercialization pathways;
2) Draw upon CSUPERBs existing network of alumni, industry experts and campus-based entrepreneurship resources, to offer tailored advice for science-based ventures;
3) Tailor a curriculum for biological sciences entrepreneurs to explore venture ideas, assess the maturity of their technology, and map out development milestones; and
4) Organize recurring, regional meetings co-hosted by industry associations and partner organizations for curious academic biological sciences entrepreneurs.

The I-Corps Biological Sciences Site will nurture CSU researchers so that they gain confidence in their entrepreneurial abilities, greater understanding of biotechnology commercialization pathways, and a better calibration of their concepts maturity level.

Broader Impacts: More than a quarter of the California State University STEM baccalaureates are from underrepresented populations. The CSU educates more Hispanic, African-American, and American Indian undergraduates than all other institutions in the state combined. The immersive learning provided by biological sciences research and entrepreneurial activity is engaging and valuable to CSU students, even the most at-risk populations. Employers and investors greatly value creative students who graduate with demonstrated accomplishments in team-based research, the ability to solve real-world problems, and experience with technology commercialization. A Biological Sciences Site program gives students and faculty access to mentors, sources of capital, business expertise, and leadership opportunities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The California State University (CSU) I-CorpsTM Biological Sciences Site provided opportunities for nascent academic entrepreneurs to explore biotechnology commercialization pathways. CSU I-Corps is a specialized, multi­-campus Site that specifically addresses the special multi­-sided markets, regulatory hurdles, and decades­-long product development lifecycles bio­entrepreneurs face.

The CSU I-Corps teaching team included experts from San Diego State University’s Colleges of Business, Engineering, Science and the Office of Technology Transfer. To offer tailored advice for research-based ventures, CSU I-Corps involved 85 biotechnology industry professionals from our network of alumni, biotechnology industry association partners, and campus-based innovation centers.

The CSU I-­Corps teaching team designed and offered I­-Corps curricula in 3-­day, one­week, and semester­-long formats. Through April 2018 CSU I-­Corps taught seven cohorts of CSU student and faculty research teams, 53 teams total, in courses to qualify for the national I-Corps Teams program. We offered five ideation workshops for CSU researchers interested in learning to identify biological sciences problems worth solving. CSU I-Corps designed and hosted the national BIO 2017 I-­Corps Bio­-entrepreneurship workshop for 24 underrepresented researchers in San Diego. We co-­hosted two regional, day-­long “Ignite 22” meetings at the Port of Los Angeles to help campus-based entrepreneurs integrate into the regional innovation ecosystem.

In total 369 individuals (team members, workshop and event participants, faculty mentors, industry mentors, and external evaluators) from 22 CSU campuses and 98 external organizations participated in CSU I-­Corps programming.

Since biotechnology commercialization is a highly partnered, decade­-long process, we are encouraged to find that 25% of the CSU I-Corps teams continue moving down commercialization paths. Three CSU I-Corps teams advanced to the national I-Corps Teams program. CSU I-Corps alumni teams formalized external partnerships, joined an incubator or entrepreneurship program, sought grant funding, or raised financing to further develop their biotechnology ventures. Other CSU I-Corps team members incorporated lessons learned into courses taught and research grants submitted. However, it is the professional growth that is most impactful for both student and faculty participants. 90% report they grew their professional networks into the private sector for the first time. Importantly to the nation’s innovation ecosystem, 87% report they can see themselves working on biotechnology commercialization teams in the future.

CSU I-­Corps provided an impactful experiential learning and professional development opportunity in biotechnology commercialization previously unavailable to our diverse student and faculty research communities. We added to our impact by including underrepresented researchers from 20 other universities nationwide in the 2017 I­-Corps Bio­-entrepreneurship workshop. This kind of experiential learning serves CSU I­-Corps alumni well as they build careers and companies off­-campus, whether they move to biotech hubs or remain in their communities. 

 


Last Modified: 08/31/2018
Modified by: Susan Baxter
